properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Westerly winds gusting at approximately 90 kilometres per hour are expected until late afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow to taper off late this morning. The fresh snow in combination with falling temperatures through the morning may cause roads to become slippery. As a result, motorists are advised to be prepared for difficult driving conditions this morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-07T22:00:11-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific frontal system will move into the northern BC interior Friday morning. This system will be followed by an Arctic front pushing through the region on Friday afternoon and then stalling over the region on Saturday. Long periods of snow are expected with total snowfall amounts of 30 to 40 cm forecast by Saturday evening. Snow will begin over Pine Pass today and will continue tonight. There is also a risk of freezing rain tonight for Pine Pass. 5 to 10 cm of snow is forecast tonight. However the more significant snowfall is expected on Friday night and Saturday. The snow will taper to flurries on Saturday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T09:45:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T17:46:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2469911435.2019
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry conditions expected across the Island late Friday afternoon and Friday night. A low pressure system is expected to bring some rain to Prince Edward Island this afternoon and into Friday. Much colder air will begin moving in from the north later in the day Friday, changing any remaining showers to periods of snow Friday afternoon or evening. Saturday will be a cold day with onshore flurries in the morning and temperatures struggling to climb above zero in many areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T06:39:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T14:40:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0877708655.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Intense snow squalls tonight into Friday. Snow squalls are forecast to develop off central Lake Huron this afternoon. They are expected to shift southward into the area this evening. The snow squalls are expected to be particularly intense tonight before slowly weakening through the day Friday. Locally heavy snow and strong winds are expected to result in reduced visibilities and difficult travel conditions at times. Local snowfall accumulations in excess of 30 cm are possible by the time the snow squalls weaken later Friday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T02:03:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T10:04:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1872570975.2019
Area: Watford - Pinery Park - Eastern Lambton County, London - Parkhill - Eastern Middlesex County, Strathroy - Komoka - Western Middlesex County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Intense snow squalls expected this evening through Friday. Snow squalls are forecast to develop off southern Lake Huron this evening and then intensify tonight, producing local amounts up to 25 cm by Friday morning. Visibilities will be significantly reduced at times due to heavy snow. Additional snowfall accumulations in the 10 to 15 cm range are expected during the day Friday bringing total snowfall accumulations to 30 to 40 cm locally. The snow squalls are forecast to weaken by Friday evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T07:40:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T15:41:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4209080861.2019

properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning. Heavy lake effect flurries will continue through the morning. Reduced visibilities in heavy snow can be expected at times along portions of Highways 11 and 17. Motorists are advised to prepare for adverse driving conditions. The flurries will weaken by this afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific front will move onto Peace River region early on Friday morning. This will be followed by an Arctic front pushing through the region in the afternoon and then stalling on Saturday. Long period of snow at times mixed with rain is expected with 20 to 40 cm total accumulation possible by Saturday afternoon. Snow will begin over Williston region and Pine pass today then change to rain or mixed with rain tonight as the warm Pacific front approaches. Rain mixed with snow is expected to develop overnight over southern Peace River region then change to snow Friday when the Arctic front pushes through. Northern Peace River region will likely stay north of the warm front and receive highest amount of snowfall. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T05:09:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T13:10:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2590370597.2019

Motorists are advised to watch for quickly changing weather conditions and adjust their driving accordingly. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and poor driving conditions expected. Total snowfall: up to 15 cm except locally 15 to 30 cm over higher terrain. Locations: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, and Green Bay - White Bay. Time span: Friday morning through Friday evening. Remarks: Snowfall accumulations are likely to vary considerably with the highest amounts expected through inland and higher elevations of Green Bay - White Bay and higher elevations between Deer Lake and Corner Brook and Deer Lake and Gros Morne. Areas near the coast and in lower lying areas through the Humber Valley are likely to see much lower amounts. The snow will taper off Friday night but flurries, snow squalls, and strong westerly winds will develop again early Saturday along the west coast and persist through the day. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-08T06:14:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T14:15:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1894277331.2019
Area: Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory for today through Friday. Flurries and local snow squalls are developing off Georgian Bay and Lake Huron and are expected to continue intermittently through Friday afternoon. While the heaviest snow squalls are expected to remain south and east of the Bruce Peninsula, portions of the Peninsula can expect locally heavy snow and reduced visibilities at times making travel difficult. Motorists are advised to watch for quickly changing weather conditions and adjust their driving accordingly. Local snowfall accumulations of 5 to 15 cm will be possible. If the snow squalls look to be more intense or persistent than currently forecast, a Snow Squall Warning may be required for the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T07:42:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T15:43:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3856513016.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather expected for parts of Nova Scotia Friday night into Saturday. A low pressure system is expected to bring some rain to the province tonight and Friday. Colder air will move in behind this system later on Friday and persist on Saturday. As this colder air arrives from the northwest, showers will turn to periods of snow late Friday afternoon or Friday evening which could give local accumulations and potentially hazardous driving conditions, especially to the Annapolis Valley, northern Nova Scotia and parts of Cape Breton Island. Saturday will be a cold and blustery day across the entire province with onshore flurries and temperatures struggling to climb above zero in some areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T06:38:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T14:39:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2782681131.2019

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. An approaching warm front will track across the BC interior today. The warm air aloft combined with below zero temperatures at the surface will result in periods of freezing rain late this morning. The freezing rain is expected to change to rain this afternoon as temperatures rise above zero. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-07T23:59:03-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Intense snow squalls late this afternoon through Friday. Snow squalls will develop off southern Lake Huron late this afternoon and then intensify tonight. These snow squalls will be capable of producing significant snowfall accumulations tonight with local amounts up to 25 cm possible. Strong winds will accompany these snow squalls resulting in blowing snow and significantly reduced visibilities at times. Conditions will slowly improve through the day Friday, though additional significant snowfall accumulations will be possible. Total snowfall accumulations of 30 to 40 cm locally will be possible by time the snow squalls weaken Friday evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain and snow followed by colder temperatures expected over New Brunswick. A low pressure system is expected to bring rain to southern New Brunswick beginning this afternoon with snow expected over northern regions. The rain/snow boundary will likely be across central New Brunswick. Rainfall amounts of 15 to 30 millimetres are possible over southern sections with 5 to 10 centimetres of snow possible for the northern and central areas of the province by Friday morning. As colder air moves into the province from the north on Friday, flurries or periods of snow are forecast to give an additional 5 to 10 centimetres of snow to central and eastern areas of the province. Reduction to visibility could create potentially hazardous driving conditions Friday afternoon and evening. Saturday will be mainly sunny but remain cold across the province as temperatures will struggle to reach the freezing mark in many areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T06:40:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T14:41:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3913728347.2019
